intro: Stenostephanus ventricosus, commonly known as the giant water flea, is a freshwater crustacean that belongs to the order Cladocera. It is characterized by its elongated, segmented body and a distinctive carapace that covers most of its body. This species is typically found in ponds, lakes, and slow-moving streams, where it plays a role in the aquatic food web. Stenostephanus ventricosus is known for its ability to reproduce both sexually and asexually, which contributes to its population stability. Its presence is often an indicator of good water quality in its habitat.
